Incident Investigation
An incident investigation procedure and process has been implemented at the Avanti facility. Each incident that has resulted in or could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release is promptly investigated, but not later than 48 hours following the incident. Per EPA RMP regulations, a catastrophic release means a major uncontrolled emission, fire, or explosion, involving one or more regulated substances that presents imminent and substantial endangerment to public health and the environment.
In the event an incident investigation is required, an incident investigation team will be established and consist of at least one person knowledgeable in the process involved and other persons with appropriate knowledge and experience to thoroughly investigate and analyze the incident. Following the investigation, a written report is prepared summarizing the following information at a minimum: date of the incident; date the investigation began; description of the incident and any contributing factors; and any recommendations resulting from the investigation. Affected personnel including contract employees will review the report after the investigation is completed. Incident investigation reports are maintained at the facility for a minimum of five years.
Emergency Response Program
An emergency response plan has been developed for the Avanti site and addresses various types of anticipated emergencies that might occur at the facility. Information within Avanti's own Emergency Action Plan include:
	Procedures for informing all Federal, State, and Local Agencies;
	Warning and evacuation systems;
	Procedures for emergency response after an accidental release of a regulated substance; and
	Protocols for other conditions including medical response, severe weather, and other acts of violence.
The plan contains response objectives and priorities, mobilization and response activities, and pertinent information for contacting outside agencies in

the Avanti facility for employees involved in operating a covered process. In addition, new employees working with a covered process receive initial training on the overview of the process and in the operating procedures, in accordance to 40 CFR Part 68.54. Training of employees include emphasis on the specific safety and health hazards, emergency response and operations including shutdown, and safe work practices applicable to the employee's job tasks. Refresher training is provided to employees working with a covered process at least every three years. Training records are maintained on site and contain the identity of the employee, the date of training, and the means used to verify that the employee understood the training.
Maintenance
Procedures shall be in place to maintain integrity to all equipment used in the covered process. Avanti shall maintain equipment safety and integrity by utilizing manufacturer documentation and providing routine training. All contractors will be upheld to Avanti's facility maintenance training plan. Inspections and records of all maintenance plans will be maintained by the facility, and will be compared to manufacturer specifications. The only covered process at Avanti is Warehouse Storage. The storage warehouse is not a facility location that will be subject to many maintenance activities, if any.
 
Compliance Audits
Compliance with the facility's RMP program is verified through safety audits that are to be performed at least once every three years in accordance with 40 CFR 68.58. The compliance audit must be conducted by at least one person knowledgeable in the process. A report of the findings will be generated following the audit and all deficiencies and/or recommendations are promptly addressed and corrective actions documented. At the time of writing this initial Executive Summary, a compliance audit has not been conducted. However, per 40 CFR 68.58, the facility will retain the two most recent compliance audit reports.

Hazard Reviews
At Avanti, hazard reviews shall be conducted to detect any possibilities for failures within the process or equipment errors and allow the facility to operate safely. The following is an outline for Avanti hazard reviews:
	Identify the hazards associated with the given Program Level 2 Process (Storage);
	List all equipment malfunctions and personnel errors that could lead to an accident;
	Highlight any safeguards that can control or prevent malfunctions and errors;
	Use checklists to inspect and monitor all processes and equipment;
	Make sure all equipment is designed to industry standards and properly installed;
	Maintain records of all reviews and corrections made at the facility;
	Update the review process every five years, or when there is a change in the process.
 
Operating Procedures
Avanti has developed operating procedures for process(es) at the facility. These procedures provide guidance to authorized employees on how equipment shall be operated and address aspects listed by the OSHA PSM standard and EPA RMP regulations. Operating procedures, at a minimum, cover the following elements:
	Initial / Subsequent Start-Up
	Normal Operations
	Temporary Operations
	Emergency Operations
	Emergency Shutdown
	Normal Shutdown
	Routine Maintenance Activities (defined by equipment operators)
The procedures are intended to provide the necessary information to authorized trained employees on how to operate RMP covered process equipment safely. Operating procedures are kept on site and are critical in the safe and environmentally sound operation of process equipment.

In the event of a release, passive and active safety systems are in place to help identify the release, as well as control and minimize its potential impact. Executive Summary

A.	Description of Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled
Avanti Polar Lipids, LLC (Avanti) is a pharmaceutical manufacturer located in Alabaster, AL. As a result of the manufacturing process, chloroform is the only regulated chemical stored at the facility in quantities that exceed the threshold quantity outlined in the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Accidental Release Prevention regulations, also known as the Risk Management Plan (RMP) Rule. Chloroform is stored in a warehouse at the facility in 55-gallon drums. The warehouse storage process is subject to RMP and is required to meet the Program Level 2 requirements outlined in the RMP Rule. Avanti is committed to operating their facility in a manner protective of their workers, the public, and the environment. As a part of this commitment, Avanti has implemented a Process Safety Management (PSM) program that complies with the Occupational Safety & Health Administration (OSHA) regulations and an RMP program that complies with the EPA's regulation outlined in 40 CFR Part 68, Accidental Release Prevention Provisions: Risk Management Program. This document has been created to satisfy the RMP requirements and to provide a description of the risk management program at the facility. This executive summary document was created to accompany the Avanti facility's initial RMP submittal to the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).
Storage Process - Program Level 2:
Chloroform is stored in this process in quantities exceeding the threshold quantity listed in 40 CFR Part 68. Chloroform is stored in a warehouse at the facility in 55-gallon drums. Given the close proximity of the 55-gallon drums, it was determined that the chloroform drums stored in the warehouse were co-located. Based on the co-location of the chloroform drums, the warehouse exceeds the threshold quantity for chloroform and was deemed a covered process as outlined in RMP.
